text:
US policing Video of off-duty officer firing gun while manhandling teen sparks protest in LA 
Hundreds in Anaheim demand arrest of police officer after footage emerged of him firing a handgun during an altercation with a 13-year-old boy Protesters march towards the officer’s home on Wednesday, 22 February. Photograph: Joshua Sudock/AP View more sharing options Monica Lopez in Anaheim, California Thursday 23 February 2017 19.00 GMT 
Hundreds of protesters have demanded the arrest of a Los Angeles police officer who was captured on camera firing a handgun during an altercation with a 13-year-old boy and other teenagers. 
Demonstrators, including groups of young people with their parents, marched through Anaheim, California , in the early morning hours on Thursday, shutting down traffic along a quarter-mile section of road. 
Activist Damion Ramirez shouted through a megaphone to about a hundred onlookers on Palais Road where, the previous day, the police office started scuffling with the young teenagers, apparently after become irritated that one of them had been walking on his lawn. 
“If somebody wasn’t filming that cop, if somebody wasn’t standing up for those kids, those kids would be gone, locked up, forgotten,” said Ramirez. “And that cop would still be carrying his gun on the street.” 
The videos depict an extended altercation between the boy, Christian Dorscht, and the off-duty officer, allegedly over words exchanged when a young girl walked on the officer’s lawn. 
The videos show teenagers at the scene urging the officer to release Dorscht, who also repeatedly asks the officer to let him go. After the dragging the boy around, the LAPD officer is approached by two other teens. Footage appearing to show the off-duty officer in an altercation with a group of teenagers was uploaded to YouTube on Wednesday. 
One attempts to break the officer’s grip on Dorscht, while another rushes in, pushing the officer into a hedge in an apparent attempt to dislodge his grip. The police officer pulls the gun from his waistband and fires after a tall teenager takes swings a punch at him. 
Twenty-four people were arrested at the protest on charges including failure to disperse, resisting arrest, and battery on a peace officer. Of those, six were minors, all of whom were released to the custody of their parents. 
During the demonstration, Christian’s mother, Alma Jimenez, held up a picture of her son and addressed the demonstrators and police, including some who were wearing riot gear. 
“Stop shooting our kids. Stop killing our kids. This is my child right here. This is my son. He’s 13 years old. He was not armed. [The LAPD officer] almost killed my son. Thanks to God’s grace, [Christian] is alive.” 
Freddie Reyes, 59-year-old Fullerton resident, was visiting with his niece in Anaheim when he saw the video and drove to the Wednesday night protest. Trump breaks from Obama with crime crackdown and 'blue lives matter' protections Read more 
“I saw what was done to the 13-year-old boy,” said Reyes. “This man had a gun. He had it in his waist. He could have killed somebody … just for [walking] over the grass. It’s not right.” 
“The thing that everybody’s concerned about is that [the officer] got to stay home while that 13-year old boy was arrested. A 13 year old,” said Reyes. 
LA resident Mateo Rubio wondered whether the officer should be retrained and asked: “How could he be fighting with some kids because they walked on his grass? Is this person going to come back into our community and treat our families the same way?” 
According to LAPD public information officer, Tony Im, the department will take 72 hours to conduct an investigation before briefing the chief of police on the administrative aspect of the case. In the meantime, the off-duty officer in the videos is on paid administrative leave. 
The Anaheim police department is handling the criminal investigation of all involved parties including the officer. 
When asked why the man in the video was not arrested, Anaheim police sergeant Jacob Gallacher said: “This is an ongoing investigation and once it’s complete, it will be turned over to the district attorney’s office for review.” 
Neighbors off the off-duty officers emphatically described local residents as respectful, “live and let live” people. They said that Palm Lane Park just a few houses down the street is a hangout for young people who cause trouble. They asked not to be identified and pointed a garage door that had been spray-painted “Fuck Pigs” and a car that had been scratched with a key.
